title.narrative: PROVISION OF QUALITY IMSAM

description.narrative: Health facilities and communities are able to provide quality Integrated Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition (IMSAM) as per the national guidelines., which contributes to Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Improved and equitable provision of evidence-based nutrition interventions for children, and for women of child-bearing age, including pregnant and lactating women by 2018.

sector.narrative: Care for children with severe acute malnutrition

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Health facilities and communities are able to provide quality Integrated Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition (IMSAM) as per thenational guidelines.

description.narrative: Between 2015 and 2018, UNICEF has supported to increase the coverage of quality care for severely acute malnourished children from 60% to 77% and this contributing to the decrease in prevalence of severe acute malnutrition among children 0-59 months from 9.9% in 2010 to 2.7% in 2018 in South-Sudan | Status:Met | As-of Date:16/12/2018
